name: Nuremberg
fun_fact: Fun fact: Nuremberg bratwurst are so strictly regulated that they must be no longer than 7-9cm (the size of your little finger) and can ONLY be called 'NÃ¼rnberger Rostbratwurst' if made within the city limits - they're protected by EU law since 2003!

hero_dishes.name: NÃ¼rnberger Rostbratwurst
hero_dishes.description: Tiny finger-sized sausages grilled over beechwood, served in portions of 6, 8, 10, or 12
hero_dishes.origin_story: First documented in 1313, these small sausages were designed to be sold through keyholes of inns after curfew! Made with pork, marjoram, and ground pepper

hero_dishes.name: Drei im Weggla
hero_dishes.description: Three bratwurst served in a crusty bread roll, the classic Nuremberg street food
hero_dishes.origin_story: The quintessential grab-and-go meal - workers have eaten this for centuries
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors throughout the old town, Christkindlesmarkt stalls

hero_dishes.name: NÃ¼rnberger Lebkuchen
hero_dishes.description: Spiced gingerbread made with almonds, hazelnuts, honey, and medieval spices
hero_dishes.origin_story: Made in Nuremberg since 1395 - the city's position on spice trade routes made it the gingerbread capital. Elisenlebkuchen (the premium version) contains NO flour
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lebkuchen Schmidt, Wicklein, DÃ¼ll - historic producers since centuries

hero_dishes.name: SchÃ¤ufele
hero_dishes.description: Slow-roasted pork shoulder with crispy crackling, served with potato dumplings
hero_dishes.origin_story: Franconian Sunday dinner tradition - the name means 'little shovel' referring to the shoulder blade shape
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Franconian restaurants, Goldenes Posthorn (Germany's oldest restaurant, 1498)

signature_drinks.name: Franconian Red Beer (Rotbier)
signature_drinks.description: Malty, reddish-brown beer unique to the Nuremberg region
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: From traditional stone steins in historic beer cellars
